topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/552483f663687217a19e1200#post_552483f663687217a19e1200
Over 50%.

Also it turns out that the whole "oh they're just waiting to marry" is complete bullshit cause the "statistics" don't take into account that humans age.  Basically the "statistics" were saying that people were just marrying at a older age when they were looking at a different generation all together; sort a statistical-centipede.  What they essentially did was that they looked at people born in the 1990's to look at marriage rates and then looked at people born in the 1980's to "prove" that people were just marrying at a older age when in reality marriages are continuing to drop.

Basically what they did was how a dog throws up and then eats it's own throw up.

topics.body:
A part of me believes this is akin to getting the scale back on the balance.

Remember back to the early 1900's how massive the birth rates were due to the need of factories to have employees on them to keep them functional. This trend still kept going until the early to mid 90's because it had become the social norm (You might notice how several families until those years tended to be from 4 to 5, even more children, if you happen to have a ton of uncles and cousins) but it slowly began to die away due to technology advancing and pretty much every work now (or at least in the near future) can be done without the need of man labor, so there's no need to have kids anymore out of a social need but rather out of wanting it, thus creating a decaying effect, because as "@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/552483f663687217a19e1200#post_552483f663687217a19e1200 and "@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/552483016368724109160200#post_552483016368724109160200 said, tastes and who people want to spend their lifes with has changed to the point is harder to pick someone who fills our standards.

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/5524857563687217a1c11300#post_5524857563687217a1c11300
Damn; my post got eaten.


Here's some good news; me and Whatevs were talking about immigration the other day and essentially what we talked about was that the usa might become a successful multicultural society.

Personally the reasons why I think it might:
A)The majority of immigrants currently aren't from war torn countries or even violent countries and are instead from asia countries where there's no active civil wars.
B)The majority of immigrants currently are fairly educated such as programmers, linguists or such.
C)The majority of immigrants currently aren't from countries we're currently at war with.

Basically a best case scenario is that say 2050:
20%-40% of usa is asian or biracial asian-other ethnicities.
This isn't a bad thing because their high levels of education are actually improving things and they're helping offset population decline.

The worst thing that might happen is if the immigration doesn't stop or slow down then you might have say california where the majority of people don't speak english, but that's not to much of a problem cause I don't think a state where the worst side effect is people don't speak english is that much a negative side effect.


Tl:dr; while marriages are on the decline this is being offset by asian immigration; worst case scenario is drastic over immigration of asian immigrants causes say california to become mostly not english speaking but other than that there's no downside.
